Questions: Which is the greatest invention to date?
Answers:
I don’t know if it necessarily counts as an ‘invention’, but I cast my vote for adult jokes in kids’ movies.

It isn’t super often that we encounter movies that are appealing to both adults and children. There’s just a lack of plot depth and intensity in children’s movies, deterring most adults, and obviously there can’t be a ton of gunfights and nudity in a kiddie movie. It’s difficult to make movies that appeal to a wide audience.

Adult jokes are the perfect solution to that issue.

I remember watching the Lego Batman movie with my parents and younger siblings a few years back. I was probably just finishing up with middle school, and I had definitely been exposed to some adult humor.

At one point in the movie, a character is talking about how

“My name’s Richard Grayson, but all my friends call me Dick.”

Batman so expertly responds:

“Well, children can be cruel.”

An expertly timed adult joke. Subtle enough that a kid wouldn’t know any better, but apparent enough that the adults in the theater chuckled.

For the rest of the movie, there are little sprinkles of mature comedy throughout:

It took me a few seconds to understand this one, but if you say it phonetically it sounds like a… naughty British epithet.

The jokes just don’t end. The plot is engaging to a younger audience, the humor keeps adults watching; it’s genius.

It’s the perfect marketing tactic. I have to applaud Hollywood screenplay writers on this one.

Questions: Who are the most unfortunate scientists of all time?
Answers:
Douglas Prasher: a gifted scientist who could unarguably have won the Nobel Prize, ended up as a shuttle bus driver.

He was the first scientist to successfully clone and sequence the genes for Green fluorescent protein
 (GFP) and shared his pioneering work with Martin Chalfie
 and Roger Y. Tsien
. He was also the first to suggest that GFP could be used as a tracer for biochemical systems. Unfortunately, within a brief period, Prasher had to quit academia since he was denied further research funding, but the latter two went on to receive Nobel Prize in Chemistry (2008). Not to mention, his works led to the foundation of multi-million dollar industries.

To emphasize the importance of his work, it can be said that, use of GFP as a biomarker or sensor has revolutionized the fields of Biochemistry, Molecular Biology, Chemical Biology, Medicine and several others. In layman's terms, GFP is used as a laser pointer to locate myriads of biomolecules. There is probably not a single lab working in Molecular Biology which does not use GFP.

However, Prasher was probably not destined to share this glory. His fate betrayed him time and again.

Following his rejection of funding application by National Institutes of Health, he was denied promotion from assistant professor to associate professor. Subsequently, he had to quit academia.
He transferred to Plant Germplasm Quarantine & Biotechnology Laboratory in Beltsville, Maryland, but he had to leave from there since the working conditions deteriorated.
He went on to work for AZ Technology - a subcontractor of NASA in Huntsville, Alabama. But after one and a half years, NASA canceled the project because of a decision to cut funding for biological research.
Dejected and heartbroken, Prasher spent an year unemployed. Then he had no choice but to take up the job of a shuttle bus driver in Penney Toyota for $8.50 an hour. He even put a sticker at the back of his car saying "Scientist needs work" and wrote his phone number.

Prasher was invited at the Nobel Prize ceremony by Roger Tsien, and both Chalfie and Tsien acknowledged him for his contribution. Prasher also expressed his pleasure by saying,

I'm really happy for them. I was really surprised that particular topic carried that much weight.

In 2012, Douglas Prasher joined the lab of Roger Tsien at University of California San Diego at his invitation.

Edit: Thank you everyone for sharing your views. I am involved in active research too as a PhD student. That's why I can really imagine how much hardship Douglas Prasher had to go through. It's good though that he is at UCSD now (in the same department I am doing PhD). However, those two decades of his life that could have been his most prolific phase, can never be brought back. I wish that no bright aspiring young researcher like him should face such hardships simply because of lack of funds.

Following his rejection of funding application by National Institutes of Health, he was denied promotion from assistant professor to associate professor. Subsequently, he had to quit academia.
He transferred to Plant Germplasm Quarantine & Biotechnology Laboratory in Beltsville, Maryland, but he had to leave from there since the working conditions deteriorated.
He went on to work for AZ Technology - a subcontractor of NASA in Huntsville, Alabama. But after one and a half years, NASA canceled the project because of a decision to cut funding for biological research.
Dejected and heartbroken, Prasher spent an year unemployed. Then he had no choice but to take up the job of a shuttle bus driver in Penney Toyota for $8.50 an hour. He even put a sticker at the back of his car saying "Scientist needs work" and wrote his phone number.

Prasher was invited at the Nobel Prize ceremony by Roger Tsien, and both Chalfie and Tsien acknowledged him for his contribution. Prasher also expressed his pleasure by saying,

I'm really happy for them. I was really surprised that particular topic carried that much weight.

In 2012, Douglas Prasher joined the lab of Roger Tsien at University of California San Diego at his invitation.

Edit: Thank you everyone for sharing your views. I am involved in active research too as a PhD student. That's why I can really imagine how much hardship Douglas Prasher had to go through. It's good though that he is at UCSD now (in the same department I am doing PhD). However, those two decades of his life that could have been his most prolific phase, can never be brought back. I wish that no bright aspiring young researcher like him should face such hardships simply because of lack of funds.', 'aiModelVersion': '1'}

Questions: What are the most risky scientific experiments ever conducted, whether in terms of life, Earth’s properties, or economic situations?
Answers:
One of the more risky experiments was done by Werner Forssmann at age 25, who performed the first cardiac catheterization. What is amazing is that he performed the procedure on himself.

At the time (1929), Werner had finished his medical education and was training as a cardiology intern. He was trying to find a way to better inject drugs into the right atrium. He had devised the cardiac catheterization experiment, but the chief did not approve of him carrying it out. He went ahead regardless but had to convince the nurse to provide him with the necessary surgical equipment. She agreed, but only if he performed the procedure on her.

He distracted the nurse by prepping her for the procedure, and then quickly made an incision in his antecubital vein followed by insertion of a urethral catheter. The nurse did not appreciate this maneuver, but she proceeded to help him make his way to the X-ray room. Once there, he advanced the catheter to his right atrium under x-ray fluoroscopic guidance. This was very risky, considering the unknown risk of perforating the wall of a vein or artery.

The chief (Schneider) was furious with Werner for disobeying him but he could not deny the importance of the procedure. He let him try it out on another patient. Unfortunately, not everyone appreciated his contribution. Shortly after taking an academic position at a hospital, he gained widespread coverage after the paper on the procedure was published. His supervisor discharged him from the position, since he thought it was a far too risky way of going about doing surgery. He may have just been intimidated by the man’s rise. Werner went back to Schneider, and he eventually was given hospital access and resources to continue with more experiments.

He was eventually awarded the Nobel prize for the original catheterization experiment, which has laid the groundwork for interventional procedures.

The Development of Interventional Cardiology

Werner Forssmann - Biographical

Werner Forssmann - Wikipedia

Questions: What are the most fascinating science facts?
Answers:
That's moon and Jupiter as seen from my terrace. The photons from sun had to travel 775 million kms to jupiter and then 558 million kms back to earth before my phone's camera could capture it.

This means that with the speed of light being equal to 299792 km/s, it takes those photons 74 minutes after they leave the sun to reach the earth. Point to be remembered is that light can circle the entire globe about 7 times in just one second. Despite such large distance involved we are able to see jupiter with our naked eyes and that's because of the enormous size of jupiter.

Not impressed yet, consider this: the same photons which took 74 minutes to travel are actually 100,000 years old. It takes such a large amount of time for it just to escape from the sun after being formed inside it's core.

Now prepare to be mind blown: For the same photon, all this time is just an instant. According to the special theory of relativity, light particles do not experience time passing. This is due to a phenomenon called time dilation. When things approach speed of light, the time slows down. The passage of time is non existant at light speed. For a photon it means that it is created and captured by my phone's camera at the same instant.

What amazes me is the marvelous thing we have on our shoulders. Our brains can comprehend and understand the world in such detail. It's truly a gift from nature.

We Are the Universe's way of experiencing itself.

Questions: What scientific photos are hard to believe but are indeed real?
Answers:
The world under a microscope is indeed bizzare. Following is a compilation of 21 objects which we see in our daily life but they look completely different under the microscope!

1. Head of a Tapeworm. 200x magnified.

2. Pollens sticking out from the stigma. 25x Magnified.

3. Retina of a mouse. 40x Magnified.

4. Mould on a tomato. 4x Magnified.

5. Portion of ant connecting its abdomen and thorax. 5x Magnified.

6. Butterfly eggs on a leaf. 7.5x Magnified.

7. Toothbrush bristles.

8. Velcro

9. An used Dental Floss

10. Rust on a Nail

11. Salt and Pepper

12. Thread and a Needle. Now we know why it is so difficult to pass it through.

13. Strawberry Seeds

14. Shark Skin

15. A shattered piece of silicon from an Intel Celeron processor.

16. Human Nerve Cell. 100x Magnified

17. First picture of a Hydrogen atom.

18. Tip of a Knife is not so sharp as we thought of.

19. Artery carrying Red Blood Cells

20. Cross section of an iPhone cable.

21. Grass

Questions: What are the most fascinating science facts?
Answers:
1) Light would take .13 seconds to travel around the Earth.

2) If you drilled a tunnel straight through the Earth (while it doesn’t rotate from North to South Pole) and jumped in, then you would start performing a Simple Harmonic Motion. If you jumped while rotation, you would bump into the side walls due to Coriolis Effect.

3) A medium-sized cumulus cloud weighs about the same as 80 elephants of very less dense of course.

4) A single bolt of lightning contains enough energy to cook 100,000 pieces of toast.

5) There are 8 times as many atoms in a teaspoonful of water as there are teaspoonfuls of water in the Atlantic ocean.

6) The average person walks the equivalent of three times around the world in a lifetime.

7) The caffeine industry has been on a downturn for the past decade at a rate of .7% reduction in demand annually, mostly due to higher demand in energy drinks and introductions of brain pills such as optimind
.

8) If you could drive your car straight up you would arrive in space (leave the atmosphere) in just over an hour.

9) More germs are transferred shaking hands than kissing.

10) The human brain takes in 11 million bits of information every second but is aware of only 40.

Questions: What scientific photos are hard to believe but are indeed real?
Answers:
These images of a cardboard cutout of a cat (in homage to Schrödinger) were photographed with light that never touched it, made possible by quantum entanglement.

Destructive and constructive interference patterns at the detectors

This is really a cool experiment and I’ll try my best to explain it in layman’s terms. You can read the full paper here
.

A green beam is divided into two at beam splitter BS1. Beam 1 goes through non-linear crystal NL1 which creates pairs of entangled yellow and red photons. The red photons get reflected at mirror D1 and the yellow photons go through. The red photons pass through the cat cardboard cutout O.

The second green beam from BS1 goes through mirror D2 and creates entangled yellow and red photons at NL2.

After NL2, the two red beams combine. If one’s to put a detector for the red beam after D3, one won’t be able to tell where a photon comes through. This is extremely important, because it allows the two yellow beams to meet at BS2 indistinguishable and create an interference pattern before hitting the photon detectors. A photon at BS2 comes from both NL1 and NL2. If we can tell where the yellow photons come from at BS2, the interference won’t happen. This is the spooky aspect of quantum mechanics.

So while none of the yellow photons ever interacted with the object, they are entangled with the red photons that did and hence carry the information to reconstruct the shape of the cat.

This technique makes it possible to illuminate an object with longer wavelength (lower energy, less destructive) and then create an image by detecting in shorter wavelength or a freely chosen wavelength where detectors are available or have superior performance.

Questions: What are the most fascinating science facts?
Answers:
Do you know what makes you addictive towards something?

Whenever you eat your favorite food, have sex, or do anything else you find pleasurable– your body releases DOPAMINE.

Dopamine is a neurotransmitter
It is one of those chemicals that is released by the hypothalamus.
It is responsible for transmitting signals in between the nerve cells (neurons) of the brain.

In a simple words, it is the chemical that makes us happy.

So whenever a person consume drugs like heroine and cocaine, they activate these nerve cells and makes them to release dopamine unnaturally,so the person feels or enjoys temporary happiness.

As this is an unnatural process, from next time, hypothalamus starts producing dopamine only in less quantities. Now, the only way to make oneself happy is consuming those drugs. Hence addicted.

Why to be 10% contended now, when you can be 10 times better in the future?

Be natural. Say NO to drugs. :)

Questions: Should Kant also be considered one of the greatest scientists on the same level as Isaac Newton and Albert Einstein for the Nebular Hypothesis?
Answers:
No — not even close.

It's an interesting observation, and yes, it is widely accepted to be true nowadays.

But it's not groundbreaking science. It's nothing revolutionary.

As a comparison — Pierre-Simon Laplace independently came up with the same result a few decades later.

But.

Laplace also worked on:

Stability of the solar system
Described as “the most important advance in physical astronomy since Newton"
Predicted black holes
Ish
Laplace transforms
Work on the speed of sound and properties of fluids such as surface tension

As well as what can only be described as a shitload of mathematics. I really mean that — a shitload.

And yet — Laplace never even gets a look in between Einstein and Newton in these lists!

And Laplace did what Kant did and more! And yet you don't hear people asserting that Laplace should be the greatest scientist ever!

If you think that 1 puny discovery puts you on the same rank as Newton and Einstein you vastly underestimate quite how pivotal and groundbreaking their work was.

Kant has very little science to his name.

I gave myself a challenge. In 20 seconds, I attempted to write down as many people who are more important to science than Kant and his nebular hypothesis (excluding Einstein and Newton).

The list is as follows:

Laplace (obviously!)
Maxwell
Faraday
Dirac
Pauli
Bohr
Planck
Bernoulli
Heisenberg
Curie
Darwin
Haber
Feynman
Hawking
Schrödinger
Galileo
Fermi
Rutherford
Boltzmann

Phew. 19 people, in 20 seconds! A little Physicist heavy, but can you blame me?

And every single one of those people contributed orders of magnitude more than Kant.

One discovery does not a great scientist make!

Kant was good at his own thing.

You don't need to artificially shoehorn him into science like this, attempts to do so just look…rather silly!

Questions: What are some of the most useful inventions that were created by mistake?
Answers:
In 1951, a WWII veteran named Wilson Greatbatch was working at an animal behaviour farm affiliated with the psychology department at Cornell. His work involved attaching experimental instruments to the animals, measuring their brain waves, heartbeats and blood pressure. One day, he had lunch with two visiting surgeons and listened to them talk about the dangers of irregular heartbeats. He imagined the heart as a radio that was failing to transmit or receive a signal. The random analogy didn’t come back to him until several years later.

A year later, Greatbatch started teaching electrical engineering at the University of Buffalo and worked part time at the Chronic Disease Institute. A physician at the institute recruited Greatbatch to help him design an oscillator that would record heartbeats using the new silicon transistors.

One day, while working on the device, Greatbatch happened to grab the wrong resistor. When he plugged it into the oscillator it began to pulse in a familiar rhythm. Thanks to his error, the resulting circuit fired exactly like a heartbeat! Here was a device that could restore the faulty signal of an irregular heart, by shocking it back into sync.

Up till then, pacemakers were bulky units which required the use of mains power. He modified the device further to be able to work in conditions inside the body and also to have long battery life. The result was an implantable, largely maintenance-free pacemaker. Within two years, he and another surgeon named William Chardack deployed the first implantable cardiac pacemaker on the heart of a dog. Since its invention, variations of his original design have now saved or prolonged millions of lives around the world.

Questions: What scientific photos are hard to believe but are indeed real?
Answers:
Jack-o’-lantern Sun
Astronaut floating in space
The death star? No it’s actually Saturn’s moon Mimas.
Red rectangle in space
Melted area in the arctic
Aurora from the ISS
CT scan of Caulophryne pelagica, a deep-sea anglerfish, which has just swallowed another fish – a softskin smoothhead, Rouleina attrita. The anglerfish is in blue.
Pluto and its blue haze
Saturn’s moons Tethys and Enceladus perfectly aligned.
Microscopic image of the head of a boll weevil
Eye of a honey bee covered in dandelion pollen

Sources:

These 10 space images look unbelievable, but are actually real (pictures)
32 Of The Year's Most Amazing Science Pictures

Questions: Who is the most badass scientist in modern history?
Answers:
I'm going to have to go with Justin O. Schmidt, inventor of the Schmidt Pain Index.

Schmidt is an entomologist who originally studied honeybees but has since expanded to ants, wasps, and arachnids.

What do all of these creepy-crawlies have in common? Venom! Specifically, venom that hurts. He had a hypothesis that painful venom evolved first in hymenoptera (ants, wasps, and bees) and then only when they became social did they need stings that actually did damage to their victim. A solitary insect just needs to inflict enough pain to escape, while a social insect needs to keep a predator away from the colony. If the predator learns that the pain is a lie, not indicating real damage, they might push through it to get to the honey or larvae the insect is protecting.

It's pretty simple to quantify toxicity in a petri dish, but to test his hypothesis Schmidt needed to rank pain. This is less simple; tissue grown in a lab can't feel pain. So he did what any good scientist would do: be the test subject.

He exposed himself to the stings of dozens of insects, recording a rating of 1 to 4, along with comments more appropriate to wine tasting than agony: A sweat bee's sting (1.0) is “light, ephemeral, almost fruity. As if a tiny spark has singed a single hair on your arm”, while a yellow jacket's (2.0) is “hot and smoky, almost irreverent. Imagine W. C. Fields extinguishing a cigar on your tongue”. One of the sadist champions, the warrior wasp, has a score of 4.0 and is described as “torture. You are chained in the flow of an active volcano. Why did I start this list?”

There are others I could mention who experimented on themselves, like Barry Marshall, who drank a concoction of Helicobacter pylori to prove that it, and not stress, was the cause of chronic stomach ulcers. But none but Schmidt (and Christopher Starr, who replicated Schmidt's research to see if his ratings were the same; they were) repeatedly tortured themselves in the name of science

Questions: Who is the most influential person in the history of Machine Learning?
Answers:
They all stood on the shoulders of Turing.

In 1936, while studying for his Ph.D. at Princeton University, the English mathematician Alan Turing
 published a paper, “On Computable Numbers, with an application to the Entscheidungsproblem,” which became the foundation of computer science.

In it Turing presented a theoretical machine that could solve any problem
 that could be described by simple instructions encoded on a paper tape. One Turing Machine could calculate square roots, whilst another might solve Sudoku puzzles. Turing demonstrated you could construct a single Universal Machine that could simulate any Turing Machine. One machine solving any problem, performing any task for which a program could be written—sound familiar? He’d invented the computer.

Turing’s legacy is not complete. In 1950 he published a paper called “Computing machinery and intelligence.” He had an idea that computers would become so powerful that they would think
. He envisaged a time when artificial intelligence (AI) would be a reality. But, how would you know if a machine was intelligent?

He devised the Turing Test: A judge sitting at a computer terminal types questions to two entities, one a person and the other a computer. The judge decides which entity is human and which the computer. If the judge is wrong the computer has passed the Turing Test and is intelligent.

Turing is easily the most influential person in this space.

Would you have Einstein without Newton? Maybe… but probably not.

Questions: What are the most fascinating science facts?
Answers:
1.

The burning zone of Candle in zero gravity is spherical in shape rather the elongated shape,cause there is no buoyant force for warmer air to rise above.

2.

Tardigrade are water-dwelling, eight-legged creature that can be grow up to 1.5mm. They are extremophiles (not true extremophiles) and survive even the gamma radiation and ionizations. They can live without water and air in space up to 30 years.

3. The slowest speed of light ever recorded was 17 metres per sec in 1998 by Professor Hau. Later on, a technique developed to stop it completely.

4. The object that is traveled farthest is Voyager 1 and it is still travelling already passed our solar system. It was launched on September 5, 1977 with the mission of carrying information related to humans, earth and our locality in universe for the extra-terrestrials to communicate us. It has traveled 139 AU (2.08E10 km) so any signal take 16 hours and 15 minutes to reach from earth to the spaceship!

5. Cymothoa exigua, or the tongue-eating louse, is a parasitic isopod of the family Cymothoidae. This parasite enters fish through the gills, and then attaches itself to the fish's tongue.

5.

Questions: What are the most fascinating science facts?
Answers:
Okay, so get ready for a journey of a lifetime:

• The French military leader and statesman Napoleon Bonaparte suffered and died from arsenic poisoning during his imprisonment on the island of Saint Helena. Forensic samples of his hair did show high levels, 13 times the normal amount, of the element.

• When you turned on the old CRD TVs, you would have seen a similar image on the TV. Roughly 1% of this image is the Microwave Radiation, belonging to the Cosmic Microwave Background. This ancient light is as old as the origin of the universe.

• This is the entire genome of a human recorded letter-by-letter, where letters represent the base pairs, roughly 162,000 pages. Out of these 162,000 pages, we differ from each other by a mere 500 pages. These 500 pages are what make you “you”.

• According to the string theory, we live in a 11 dimensional space as opposed to 4. But, the 7 dimensions are so small, they fail to have any affect at scales larger than the Planck length.

• No matter what, you cannot outrun a photon in vacuum.

• A photon never gets old. Thus, a photon realeased during the big bang is of the same age today as it was then.

This is becuase photons being massless, use all of their energy to move in the 3 physical dimensions. As a result, they have no energy left to show motion in the time dimension.

• If you could somehow run at a significant fraction of the speed of light, you would experience time dilation, i.e. significant slowing down of time.

• In the string theory, there is a mathametically proven claim for wormholes to exist. Wormholes are tears in the fabric of space, which join different regions of space, thereby forming inter-spacial bridges. Although, these are extremely microscopic.

(I hope you did like my answer. Please don't forget to upvote and follow if you did find this relevant as it will encourage me to write more answers like these in the future. The comment section is open for suggestions and healthy debates. See ya'll next time. Take care, stay healthy.)

Edit: Thanks for the love and support guys. This is my first answer to cross a thousand views. Do check the answer on my space “The Finch”. You'll love it, for sure. Keep sharing. Love you all!

P.S.- Fact #4 has been edited as suggested in the comments to prevent spread of false knowledge. My apologies.

Questions: What are some cool inventions?
Answers:
PENCIL WITH POTENTIAL

What if instead of throwing your pencil stubs away you could plant them and have them grow into something delicious, beautiful, and fun? What if pencils could grow?

CSAIL graduate Mario Bollini has transitioned from programming robots that bake cookies
 to developing pencils that when planted will sprout fresh herbs and vegetables. In a new endeavour called Sprout, Bollini, who was previously a member of CSAIL Director Daniela Rus’ Distributed Robotics Lab, and fellow MIT classmates from a product development course have developed a “pencil with potential.”

Each pencil has a different seed located inside. When the pencil is too short to use, users can plant it, and when watered the pencil will sprout anything from cherry tomatoes to radishes and marigolds.

Sprout is a pencil with a seed inside. When it's too short to use, it can be planted at home, at the office, or in the classroom.

We really like writing with wooden pencils. They have a tactile feel that even the best mechanical pencils can't match. When Sprout is too short to use, it can be planted to grow into a wonderful flower, herb, or vegetable.The seed capsule is water activated, the first few times you water Sprout dissolves the protective capsule and starts the seed's germination.

Isn’t it amazing?

Source: Sprout: a pencil with a seed

Images: Google

Thank you for reading :)

Questions: What are some unintended science inventions in history?
Answers:
Popsicles were unintenionally invented by an 11 year old.

In 1905, Frank Epperson (as I said, he was 11 year olds at that time) left his cup, which was filled by water, powered soda and a stick in the cold.

Surprise, it froze!

Today, the toal ice cream market of more than 59 billion USD[1] and I guess his random invention contributed to that.

Footnotes

[1] Size of the global ice cream market 2013-2024 | Statistic

Questions: What are the most fascinating science facts?
Answers:
Superfluid helium can leak through glass and climb out of its container




Superfluidity is a state of matter
 in which the matter
 behaves like a fluid with zero viscosity
; where it appears to exhibit the ability to self-propel and travel in a way that defies the forces of gravity
 and surface tension


In simple words, Superfluids have zero viscosity [eg. ketchup is more viscous than water] and zero friction. So low, that they can climb out of a wall of container and can leak through glass.

Liquid Helium behaves as a superfluid at -270.92 deg Celsius

Here's an image of Superfluid Helium-4 flowing out of a glass container


Still sounds unrealistic? Here's a video



Sources:
1. Wikipedia - Superfluidity

2. Science Alert - Superfluid helium can leak through glass and climb out of its container

Questions: What scientific photos are hard to believe but are indeed real?
Answers:
i am going to don't go microscopic because lots of the responses mention equivalent.

so, here is my listing:

Star-shaped cataract

A punch when you look at the face left a person in India starry-eyed — actually. Doctors reported in an instance report, that he formed a rosette cataract after getting smacked in face.

Sun's north pole

A composite image of sunlight's north pole. The images, taken because of the European area department (ESA) and uploaded online in December 2018, provide a glimpse of sunlight with never ever already been seen directly.

Earth turtle

This amazing picture was taken by Washington university's Turtle Task power. The team spotted the turtle while investigating turtle migration. She had just emerged from a muddy opening inside soil by a dried-up pond.

Sun explodes

NASA's Solar Dynamics Observatory used computer models to fully capture snapshots of the unseen solar technology, with spectacular outcomes. The computer-enhanced ultraviolet photo reveals a model associated with sunshine's magnetic-field lines swirling out from the stars surface.

Feather boa

Divers near northern brand new Zealand spotted this drifting “ feather boa\" undulating through the water. The gorgeous ribbon of gold is called a pyrosome and it isn't an individual animal, but instead, a colony of tiny pets known as tunicates.

Quintuple rainbow

While shooting a sunset in nj-new jersey, photographer John Entwistle had been greeted by a sky coated with five rainbows Supernumerary rainbows such as this one contains a primary rainbow (the brightest of bunch) and about two other rainbows that are generally speaking less vivid.

Hurricane Florence eye

This beautifully nonetheless and peaceful violent storm attention belies the havoc Hurricane Florence wreaked over the southeastern U.S. in September 2018.

Pufferfish art

whenever it's time to get a hold of a mate, male Japanese pufferfish when you look at the Torquigener genus invest seven days, twenty four hours daily, sculpting a complex but in the end momentary masterpiece of design to the sandy seafloor. Plus they do it al by wiggling their fins to produce complex ridges and valleys.

Thor's well

Called Thor’s Really at this spot off the coastline of Oregon, there’s a 20-foot-deep (6 yards) chasm in which, right before and after high tide, frothy waves shoot out of the hole and then strain back off. Naturally, this really is significantly of an illusion, albeit an entirely gorgeous one.

Algae bloom swirls

NASA's Operational Land Imager from the Landsat-8 satellite spied a really intense algal bloom inside Baltic water in July. As for exactly what developed the sea art, experts suspect a mix of blue-green algae (also known as cyanobacteria) and a chlorophyll-rich phytoplankton known as diatoms.

Steve aurora

This mystical and majestic ribbon of purple light slashing throughout the Canadian sky has a fittingly mystical title: STEVE. At the time, they thought Steve ended up being just another the main aurora borealis, or northern lights. But experts have since discovered that Steve is one thing very different — then one \"entirely not known\" to science.

New brain cells

Your mind keeps making new neurological cells , even as you receive older. And they're breathtaking.

Whale's rainbow sneeze

Fortunately, wildlife professional photographer Domenic Biagini was in the proper location in the right time and energy to capture this image .Being an oxygen-breathing mammal, a whale exhales a combination of hot air, some water vapor and many whale snot. In this whale's instance, the water vapor caught the sunlight simply perfectly — in the same manner raindrops do if they refract light into its constituent colors, creating rainbows.

Exploding ants

When gross is … stunningly cool-looking. Treetop-dwelling ants from Southeast Asia defeat their enemies by blowing themselves up, rupturing their particular mobile wall space and spattering harmful human anatomy fluids around prey.

Yellowstone magma pit

Using a pc model, the group unearthed that 7 million several years of underground unrest led around the development of the twin magma chambers that animate the Yellowstone caldera in modern times. Shown right here, the grand prismatic springtime which will be among the numerous signs and symptoms of this concealed supervolcano.

Penguin supercolony

Lots and plenty of penguins were found nesting on Antarctica's risk islands.They estimate, based partly on poop spots (yes, poop) seen in aerial snapshots, that about 1.5 million adelie penguins are living and reproduction on this area.

Lava dome fountain

Ordinarily, volcanoes erupt lava in effective jets appear like fountains gone crazy. In this picture — grabbed Oct. 11, 1969, in Hawaii — the lava spurted out symmetrically, creating an aesthetically pleasing lava-dome water fountain.

Super blue blood moon

A Super blue bloodstream moon lunar eclipse graced the heavens and dazzled Earth-bound humans during the early morning hours of Jan. 31 2018, an event that hadn't happened in 152 years.

Spiral bee hive

The Australian stingless bees (Tetragonula carbonaria) in this image, captured by entomologist Tim Heard and posted to Reddit in January 2018, worked together to build this spiral nest that looks delectable to eat (or maybe not). The spiral-shaped towers are called brood combs, and they link together hundreds of egg chambers, forming a staircase of developing young.

source: 100 Best Science Photos of 2018

Questions: Is it just me or has the acronym 'B.C.E' become over used all of a sudden when referring to history? I understand it is often used when talking about scientific history but why do we have to complicate things? Apparently, B.C is exactly the same.
Answers:
“What does ‘BC’ stand for?”

”Before Christ.”

”Oh. So Christ was born in the year 0?”

”No, there isn’t a year 0.”

”So he was born in the year 1 then?”

”No.”

”Was he born in the year 1BC then? Was he born one year before Christ?”

”No.”

”This… is confusing. So what year was he born?”

”Theres no consensus, but probably between 6BC and 4BC.”

”So Jesus was born six years before Jesus was born?”

”Kinda… this is why ‘BC’ isn’t a helpful term.”

”Shall we call it ‘BCE’ then? That’s less confusing as it means ‘Before the common era’?”

”Yes. Using BCE is much less confusing.”

”This… is confusing. So what year was he born?”

”Theres no consensus, but probably between 6BC and 4BC.”

”So Jesus was born six years before Jesus was born?”

”Kinda… this is why ‘BC’ isn’t a helpful term.”

”Shall we call it ‘BCE’ then? That’s less confusing as it means ‘Before the common era’?”

”Yes. Using BCE is much less confusing.”', 'aiModelVersion': '1'}

Questions: What is the oldest recorded event in history?
Answers:
That can be found in the Cave of Maltravieso in Spain.

The hand outlines on the wall are estimated to be made 65,000 years ago. [1]

Correct photo thanks to the comment of Tudor Florescu.

This predates the supposed arrival of modern humans in Europe, so it’s possible that the outlines were left by Neanderthals.

They were present, that was the event. It’s also the first recorded case of Banksy style graffiti using templates.

The oldest cave painting made by modern humans dates back to around 40,000 years ago, like this hunting scene found in the Cave of El Castillo.

It was probably tied to a long forgotten story. Like, how uncle Harry once managed to shoot two bucks and a hind all by himself.

Thanks for asking, Diana.

Footnotes

[1] The world's oldest cave paintings were probably made by Neanderthals

Questions: Who is the least significant person in history that we've all probably heard of?
Answers:
Eva Braun’s only claim to fame is that she was Hitler’s lover, only having been married a couple days before they committed suicide.

Aside from that, Eva Braun has consistently provided historians with very little of substance, making them very disappointed in the process of trying to dig up anything interesting. By all accounts, Eva Braun was not much more than a normal woman living in Nazi Germany. When she and Hitler became lovers in 1932, virtually no one knew. Only very close friends knew or very high-ranking officials. Hitler wanted people to see him as a strong unmarried man which he believed would help him keep a stable political reputation. As such, she never appeared with him in person at official events and the country never knew about her existence until after the war ended.

She also wasn't a very political person at all. For example, she never joined the Nazi Party or held any specific views. Records say that she was into things most young women of her age liked back then (she was 17 when she and Hitler first met in 1929): clothes, sports, and movies. Hitler also kept her out of any meetings he had with Nazi officials or business leaders and she even had her own room in Hitler’s Berlin house. The most ‘political’ thing she ever did in regards to the war was complain to Hitler about the possibility of banning women’s cosmetic items as part of the war’s rationing during the transition into a total war economy. A complaint that Hitler abided by halting production instead of banning them.

Eva Braun’s sex life with Hitler was also pretty normal too despite all the conspiracies. One charming thing that Eva Braun said about this is when she saw a picture of Neville Chamberlain on Hitler’s sofa and giggled: “Oh if he only he knew what that sofa has seen!”

So yeah, Eva Braun was pretty much just a normal woman who happened to be Hitler’s lover. Nothing super interesting about her which has disappointed historians. Kinda funny really

Questions: When Charles Darwin set sail on the HMS Beagle, what did he and most of his contemporary scientists think about the origin of species?
Answers:
The scientific community had already long since moved away from the Mosaic chronology and into ideas of deeper time (though not as deep as we’ve later realized), and the idea of evolution had been current for more than a generation. Indeed, Charles Darwin’s grandfather Erasmus had written on the topic. Evolution, in the broad sense of change over time, was fairly evident, at least within the scientific community.

What nobody had a good handle on was a mechanism for how evolution happened. Why did species change and how, exactly, did these changes come about? These were the great unknowns at the time. Darwin’s big contribution, then, was not the idea of evolution, but the idea of evolution as a sort of natural analogue of the well-understood practice of selective breeding. He was able to flesh out an explanation for observed facts.

Questions: What are some of the most ingenious calculations in history?
Answers:
These days, Edmund Halley is best known for the comet that is named after him—one which famously returns and grazes our night sky once every 75 years or so.

What many overlook, however, is that he was also an incredibly clever scientist—one with a knack for solving seemingly uncrackable problems. Among fellow scientists, he developed a reputation: give him a problem, and he would arrive at a solution (or at least try damn hard to reach one).

It was with this attitude in mind that the Royal Society approached him with a task in the early 1700’s. The English government had asked them for an estimate of the total landmass of England and Wales—and the Society was struggling.

Given the exceedingly unusual shape of the two countries, any physical survey would be exceedingly expensive. Similar issues impeded a traditional mathematical calculation of the landmass’s area.

Halley went about it in a very different way.

First, he found the most accurate map of the two countries available. Then, with the paper copy in hand, he cut out the shape of the two countries extremely carefully.

He then weighed the map piece with careful precision and noted the figure.

Finally, Halley cut out the largest complete circle he could from the center of the map piece and weighed that circle.

The radius of the final circle measured 69.33 miles. After comparing the measured weights, he figured that the map piece weighed roughly four times the circle. Hence, the combined area of England and Wales… was just four times the area of the circle.

His final measurement was only 1% off today’s figures.

It’s safe to say the fellows at the Royal Society were probably chuckling at themselves for that one.

Questions: Why was Galileo Galilei almost crucified when he said the earth was round?
Answers:
He wasn’t “almost crucified”, but given house arrest, and that the Earth is round had been the official doctrine of the Catholic Church for well over a millennium at that point (and before that, they simply had no opinion; anyone educated simply knew the Earth was round since at least 300 BCE so there was never any argument). Galilei was sentenced for saying the Earth went around the Sun, and for being a total dick about it.

You might be thinking of Giordano Bruno, who was burnt at the stake at roughly the same time, but it was not for any cosmological claims: it was for persistently preaching that people should abandon Christianity and start worshipping the old Egyptian gods. Yes, burning him at the stake was totally unreasonable by modern standards, but given the place and time, he might have been a wee bit less brazen about it. Popes have been known to be quite unreasonable when it comes to paganism. I consider myself to be quite liberal regarding LGBTQ issues, but I still wouldn’t go around arranging public viewings of gay pornography in Iran. (He also advocated a heliocentric model, but that wasn’t actually the issue.)

Questions: In your opinion, what is the worst ever faux pas by a well-respected scientist?
Answers:
William Shockley was one of the inventors of the transistor and a Nobel prize winner. He was then, quite literally, the creator of “Silicon Valley”, when he founded Shockley Semiconductor Laboratory
, just about two miles or so from Quora’s office in Mountainview.

Unfortunately, he was by all accounts a raging asshole, and his company more or less imploded when eight senior employees demanded that he be replaced. When he stayed in power, the Traitorous eight
 left to start Fairchild Semiconductor, co-invent the integrated circuit, then found their own companies (like Intel, AMD, and Kleiner Perkins).

Anyhow, you might think that driving away colleagues who went on to literally change the world was the faux pas, but no. Shockley then decided that his intellect would be better utilized promoting Scientific Racism, which he did with great vigour, declaring

“My research leads me inescapably to the opinion that the major cause of the American Negro's intellectual and social deficits is hereditary and racially genetic in origin and, thus, not remediable to a major degree by practical improvements in the environment”

Needless to say, he was not particularly missed when he died.
